div.p: POEMS ON THE MOST Solemn Subjects.

lg.l: HARK! Wiſdom's crying in our ſtreets,
With her inviting voice;
Addreſſing every one ſhe meets,
Of her to make their choice.
Come, come, we'll hear her ſing awhile,
We'll hear her pleaſant lays;
Her language is in heavenly ſtile,
Hark! Hark! hear what ſhe ſays?
"You need not journey here by land,
Nor take a voyage by ſea
To ſearch me out, for here I ſtand,
And daily wait on thee.
Will not you now me entertain,
And lodge me in your heart?
If you but will—I'll there remain,
My wiſdom there impart.
I daily know what's done in heaven;
I am converſant there;
Riches immenſe to me are given,
You each may have a ſnare.
If you want riches to endure,
With me they're to be found:
Riches in heaven I will enſure,
They there ſhall you ſurround.
If you're ambitious for a crown,
And wiſh to reign a king,
I'll ſeat you on a glorious throne,
I'll you to honour bring.
Perhaps thou never ſaw on earth,
A king's coronation day;
And here are not a prince by birth,
In heaven you one ſhall be.
The New Jeruſalem above,
That city great and grand,
Where all is peace, where all is love,
Your throne ſhall ever ſtand.
A crown of life I'll there enſure;
A king you there ſhall be;
Honours immortal and all pure,
I'll daily roll on thee.
Will overwhelm you all with joy,
And you like monarchs ſing;
Eternity will yield employ
That well becomes a king.
You'll there behold the bleſſed God,
And Jeſus Chriſt his Son;
Your tongues will there ſpread all abroad,
What they for you have done.
Angels will liſten with ſurpriſe.
And ſmile to hear you ſing,
And you'll look round with pleaſant eyes,
As happy as a king.
You will remember well the ſtreet,
The houſe you liv'd in here,
The very place where you ſhall meet,
To you will e'er be dear.
You from your windows at me gaze,
By two, by three and four,
And here I travel your highways,
And call at every door.
If you refuſe this offer'd bliſs,
This glorious crown—this throne,
I'll advertiſe you juſt of this,
The loſs will be your own."
YE young, ye fair, your roſed cheeks
May promiſe you old age;
But yet a few more ſetting ſuns
And death may you engage.
He with his cold relentleſs hands
May force your ſouls away;
Nor can a crowd of weeping friends,
Perſuade him then to ſtay.
Then ſcenes of an eternal date,
Will open to your view;
They will be ſcenes of long diſtreſs,
Or laſting joys to you.
They will be ſcenes of long diſtreſs,
If you ha'n't Chriſt your friend;
But if you him ſecure in time,
You'll make a happy end.
Oh! then angels will have their wiſh,
All glad to ſee you come;
They will with twice ten thouſand tongues,
Congratulate you home.
But if you miſs of Chriſt while here,
You'll be forever curs'd,
And every one in heaven will ſing,
"God's holy true and juſt."
MOURNERS in Zion here below,
Oh, 'tis a bleſſed path you go!
What though there's troubles croſs your way
And ſorrows meet you every day.
What though the world rejoice all round,
And are at heart both whole and ſound;
While you do here a mourning go,
And look like one all form'd for woe.
If ſorrows ſtill do you betide,
Oh! don't for kingdoms turn aſide,
But perſevere unto the end,
And there you'll meet an able friend.
'Twill be a friend worth while to ſee,
A friend that will rejoice in thee;
A friend that will with all his heart,
A long reward to you impart.
He'll claſp you (ſmiling) by the hand,
And lead you to the heavenly land.
Heaven will rejoice to ſee you come,
And you'll rejoice to find your home.
He'll ſeat you down on Zion's mount,
Where all your ſorrows you'll recount,
And when the ſharpeſt you review,
Oh! how 'twill heaven endear to you!
You'll then look round the heavenly fields,
See the production that ſome yields,
And can no longer hold your tongue,
And thus (perhaps) begin your ſong;
"Oh! I'm arriv'd to endleſs day!
And tears for ages wip'd away!
Ages they are of endleſs date,
That none on earth can 'numerate.
Oh! how my heart on earth did ache!
I really thought ſome times 'twould breaks.
Some times I thought with every breath,
I muſt reſign myſelf to death.
But tribulation I have paſs'd,
I've ſeen an end of all at laſt;
I to my Father's houſe am come,
To never, never go from home.
Here I ſhall take my laſting reſt,
Emboſom'd by the ever bleſs'd;
He doth himſef to me impart,
Which fills with joy my inmoſt heart.
The proſpect I behold is long,
That I ſhall here employ my tongue;
Ages I ſee of heavenly mirth,
Oh, welcome heaven, and farewell earth!"

div.head: Death at the Door of a Sinner.

lg.l: HARK! hark! there's rumbling at my door,
Pray tell me who is there?
A ſtrange unuſual noiſe it is,
'Tis Death, I really fear.
If 'tis, O what, what ſhall I do?
For him I'm unprepar'd;
To prayers and cries both loud and ſhrill,
He will pay no regard.
He'll claſp me with his death cold hands,
My body wrapt in duſt;
No way to ſhun him can be found,
But with him go I muſt.
But oh the proſpect I behold!
It wounds me to the heart;
My ſoul muſt wing to Chriſt my Judge,
To hear that word, depart!
Depart to everlaſting fire,
With devils there to dwell;
There weep, there wail, there gnaſh my teeth.
World without end in hell.
MY ſoul! my ſoul! come thou aſcend,
The height of Calvary's mount,
There, there behold your heavenly friend,
His ſufferings there recount.
See him by foes all circl'd round,
Oh burſt mine eyes with tears,
See there his croſs lie on the ground,
See hammer, nails and ſpears.
There ſee thoſe inoffenſive limbs,
The painful irons meet;
Hard-hearted ſoldiers from their bands,
There nail his hands and feet.
Behold him reared in the air,
With hands extended wide,
His precious blood a ſtreaming there.
from hands and feet and ſide.
Behold him hanging in diſtreſs,
And GOD from him withdrew,
And earth and hell no more nor leſs,
With vengeance him purſue.
But yet when yielding up the ghoſt,
Their wellfare doth purſue,
Father (he prays) do them forgive,
They know not what they do.
He dies—nature to mourning goes—
The ſun can't bear the ſight,
The rocks can't now take their repoſe,
And day has took its flight.
My ſoul you was concern'd in this,
Your ſins did bring him there;
He ſhed that precious blood for thee,
To it come ſtraight repair.
There waſh and cleanſe from ſin—come do
With him prepare to dwell,
Or you muſt join his murderers too,
With them muſt ſink to hell.

div.head: Remember thy Creator in the Days of thy Youth.

lg.l: REMEMBER now you that are young,
To your Creator fear;
Let words drop daily from your tongue,
That can't but bring him near.
Him entertain, while free from cares;
While you have youth in prime;
For days will come all unawares,
When pleaſure wings from time.
Angels thoſe heavenly ſuns of light,
Think of you every day,
And every morn and every night,
Think ſtrange of your delay.
Don't let the ſilver cord of life,
Be waſting every day,
When gone, you will aloud proclaim,
I've flung the whole away.
Don't let the golden, golden bowl
Be broken in your hands,
While at the fountain fill each ſoul,
There plenty round you ſtands.
Old age is haſtening every day,
And death is on the wing,
When all your time is flung away,
This mournful ſong you'll ſing,
Alas for me! I now muſt die,
Muſt bid the world farewell,
My body in the grave muſt lie,
My ſoul likewiſe in hell.
If I look back when I was young,
It yields me no relief;
Then all was pleaſure—all was ſong—
That fills me now with grief.
I diſregarded then my GOD,
Rejected then his Son;
Oh lovely morning I then had,
Alas from me 'tis run!
When I review my buſy years,
When I had life in prime,
To ſeek the favour of my GOD,
I then could find no time.
And now upon times utmoſt bound,
Bereav'd of comfort be;
No gleam of hope can now be found,
Oh gloomy hour with me!
My hoary head, O GOD! is gone,
'Twill be no crown to me,
Tho' favour'd here with four-ſcore years,
Not one employed for Thee.
But yonder ſee the thickening cloud,
That han't yet on me burſt,
But at the moment I leave time,
Then on me roll it muſt.
'Twill ſink me under wrath divine,
Where ever I muſt dwell,
And there exchange my miſpent years,
For miſerable hell.

div.head: The Doctrine of univerſal Salvation, examined and rejected.

lg.l: MY ſoul with ſerious care attend,
To every day and hour;
Oh! come ſecure your heavenly friend,
Now while 'tis in your power:
Oh! let not time all ſlip away,
And go not heedleſs on;
Death may o'ertake you now to-day,
And you cry out, undone.
Undone for days that have no date,
For years that can't be told;
Eternity when all's too late,
Your ruin will unfold.
Pay no regard to wandering ſtars,
Which triumph ••• here, 〈…〉 ;
Courageous ones, bold ſons of Mars,
How ſweet they ſing of hell!
'Tis only there to pay a debt,
Which juſtice doth require;
'Tis but one thouſand years to ſweat,
And thus be purg'd with fire.
Then liberating work begins,
On young good-natur'd ſons;
The willful ſtubborn, old in ſins,
Will prove bold hardy ones.
Ages of ages multiply'd,
By what they cannot tell,
When all will lay their wills aſide,
And wing in crouds from hell.
All to aſcend to God above,
To celebrate his name;
To ſing aloud redeeming love;
Redeeming love proclaim.
My ſoul it is not thus with him,
That's holy true and juſt;
All that they ſay is but a whim,
Which now reject you muſt.
His juſtice he'll not lay aſide,
But ſtrew it all around;
In heav'n ſpreads joy both far and wide,
In hell doth all confound.
Both heaven and hell depend on this;
In this they both agree,
They both believe their lot is caſt
For an eternity.
To thoſe that do this diſbelieve,
I'll tell you when you die,
A diſappointment great you'll meet,
Confounded with a lie.
SINNERS, awake! awake! awake!
For your eternal all's at ſtake;
If you let time neglected run,
You'r for eternity undone.
The days you have this ſide the grave,
Are precious jewels—do them ſave—
'Tis all you'll have beneath the ſun,
Oh, let the prize by you be won!
Don't think as ſome poor creatures do,
My ſins are ſmall, their numbers few;
And Chriſt cannot with all his heart,
Pronounce to me that word, depart.
Sure ſome reſerve he'll have in ſtore,
In hell I ſha'n't be evermore;
Some period ſure beyond the grave,
From hell I ſhall redemption have.
Come this I'll drop now from my tongue,
It matters not where you belong,
Whether you're Gentile or a Jew,
Eternal mis'ry waits for you.
Hell is a poor miſtaken place,
To think of mercy or of grace:
There no repentance can be given;
No pardons paſs the ſeal of heaven.
It is a world—but who reigns there—
Why nothing elſe but black deſpair:
He revels there in endleſs night,
Sporting with groans that can't him fright.
He'll be commiſſion'd from above,
(By him you call'd while here, all love,)
To bind you with his laſting chains,
Confine you to thoſe dreary plains.
Where you'll have leiſure long and great,
To mourn your folly when too late;
You there will ſure remember well,
The ſongs you heard concerning hell.
No eaſe can they afford you there,
You muſt ſhake hands with black deſpair;
With hope muſt take a long farewell,
Eternity muſt waſte in hell.
Oh now I muſt entreat the world,
This doctrine from you may be hurl'd!
If you embrace it till you die,
In your right-hand you'll find a lie.

div.head: The Death of a Sinner, and his Puniſhment eternal.

lg.l: WHAT anguiſh muſt arreſt
A dying ſinner here,
When he beholds on all ſides round,
No friend nor helper near,
That's long been gathering wrath,
And fill'd his wicked ſoul,
That ſees the fruit of all now ripe,
And he muſt reap the whole.
Oh harveſt ſad indeed!
'Tis everlaſting woe,
He leaves the world, and all things here,
And down to hell muſt go!
Thoſe fiery billows plunge,
That world muſt long explore;
Manſions of woe will him invite,
And open ſting each door.
And enter in he muſt,
Muſt all within behold,
Muſt ſee the furniture that's there,
His arms muſt it infold.
Eternity goes on,
By long and ſlow degrees;
No grace or mercy he expects,
Nor ſpends one thought on theſe.
No Univerſaliſt
Will preach his doctrine there,
His mouth will he forever ſhut,
And ſealed with deſpair.
Could he but entertain,
That he with GOD ſhould dwell,
When years a million had run out,
'Twould yield him ſongs in hell.
Deſpair would quit that world,
And hope ſoon in would go,
And all his proſpects quite through hell,
Would ſurely baniſh woe.
Hope would ſupport him there,
It never would depart,
A bleſt eternity he'd ſee,
'Twould hourly cheer his heart.
This an't believ'd in hell,
They don't it entertain,
Deſpair doth ever them ſurround;
O'er them will ever reign.
And he that there arrives,
Deſpair will claſp him round,
There's no redemption from that place,
By him will e're be found.
He'll know eternity,
As dreadful as it is,
With all its anguiſh—all its woe,
He muſt embrace as his.
Muſt ſee a ſight moſt ſad;
Muſt ſee that heaven is gone;
Muſt ſee and feel 'tis he alone,
Which has himſelf undone.
LORD, what ſhall I thy creature do,
To ſhun thy Spirit, hide from you;
Or where ſhall I now take my flight,
Sit down, and ſay you're out of ſight?
If I to heaven ſhould wing my way,
And there allow'd one hour to ſtay;
See who is there—ſee what they do,
And hear them talk and ſing of you.
This thought direct would me arreſt,
That you did reign in every breaſt:
There holy! holy! holy rings,
To Thee who art the King of kings.
If I from thence ſhould viſit hell;
See how they look—ſee where they dwell;
This thought would pierce me thro' and thro',
That you was there, and I with you.
Although I there my hands ſhould wring,
Thy juſtice anguiſh there ſhould bring,
I'm bold to ſay, and now declare,
That beauty reigns triumphant there.
If I before the morning light,
Gird up my loins all trim and tight;
Skip to the Eaſt and meet the ſun,
And with him twice twelve hours ſhould run.
O fool! O fool! I ſure ſhould be,
To think I'd then got rid of Thee:
'Twould be thy hand through all the way,
That would ſupport me night and day.
Should I attempt to ſhun the light,
And ſingle out the darkeſt night;
That would with thee be heavenly noon,
Brighter by far than ſun or moon.
Should I attempt to explore all ſpace,
Swifter than lightning ſpeed my race,
That ſolitary place an't found,
Where I could ſay you wer'n't all round.
'Tis't poſſible to ſhun thy face,
Throughout the vaſt extent of ſpace.
To ſin, oh may I never dare!
Since thou my GOD, art every where.
GREAT is the day, 'tis coming on
As ſwift as time rolls o're,
When the laſt trump will loud proclaim,
That time ſhall be no more.
Then he that once on Calvary di'd,
Will on a throne deſcend,
And ſpread his orders far and wide,
The ſolemn day to attend.
The earth and ſea 'll obey his voice,
And ſtraight reſign their dead,
The ſaints will then aloud rejoice,
But ſinners out cries ſpread.
Before his bar they muſt appear,
They can't from it retire;
There each his character muſt hear,
From him that's rob'd in fire.
His friends he'll ſever from his foes,
And ſeat at his right hand;
But thoſe that did him here oppoſe,
He'll to his left command.
Thoſe on his right he'll thus addreſs,
'Twill charming, charming be;
My Father's bleſſed ones now come,
A kingdom take from me.
His foes muſt hear quite the reverſe,
Depart ye curſed 't will be,
To everlaſting fire prepar'd,
For devils and for thee.
LORD, may I ever do,
As good old Jacob did;
With the like zeal may I purſue,
The mercies which I need.
When I retire for prayer,
May it Peniel be;
O Jacob's God! do meet me there,
Converſe a while with me.
And may I be engag'd,
To wreſtle with my might,
And not give o'er the heavenly ſute,
Tho' morning brings the light!
And may I then thee claſp,
And never let thee go,
'Till I obtain what I requeſt,
'Till thou my wiſh beſtow!
Then I can halt, be lame,
Can any trial meet;
For theſe if I can thee obtain,
Th' exchange, oh, 'twill be 〈◊〉 !
OH ſinners! what, what will you do,
When time with you ſhall end?
For then look round which way you will,
Ye can't behold a friend.
The GOD that your creator is,
Will be your righteous foe;
You'll ſee him in this doleful hour,
Unreconcil'd to you.
The dear Redeemer who did die,
Entirely for your ſake,
He will beſide his Father ſit,
Of you no notice take.
The holy Spirit that did ſtrive,
That woo'd you like a friend,
He will from you be far retir'd,
His treaty's at an end.
The holy angels hovering round,
The bleſſed One in Three,
Each to the other will make known
They've no delight in thee.
The holy ſaints, from firſt to laſt,
Will pay you no regard;
Each will be conſcious to himſelf,
You've met a juſt reward.
Come turn your eyes where darkneſs reigns,
That doleful world of woe,
Among the millions that there dwell,
You'll find each one your foe.
Friendſhip will from you er'e be fled,
Ne'r to return to you,
Its long departure you'll bewail,
And won't know what to do.
Then groans eternal will commence,
And you be fill'd with pain;
Ages will ever paſs you by,
But no relief can gain.
You muſt embrace eternal woe,
Muſt make your bed in hell,
Far from relief, and far from friends,
You there muſt ever dwell.
